title: Top of the pops; Did pop music peak in 1971?
text:
Music's greatest year is a perennial argument among pop fans, yet the conversation is conducted without a shared set of assumptions. Must the “greatest year” be one in which the landscape of music irrevocably changed, or one in which several cherished albums or singles were released? Mr Hepworth cheers for 1971 because he values albums above all else, and this was a landmark year for extended plays, with Joni Mitchell's “Blue”, David Bowie's “Hunky Dory”, Marvin Gaye's “What's Going On”, “Led Zeppelin IV” and “The Staple Swingers” (from the Staple Singers, pictured). If you adore singles best of all, however, you might suggest 1965 or 1966 as the strongest contenders, as the British charts contained a plethora of songs still in the public consciousness. Among the top ten hits of 1965 were “Subterranean Homesick Blues” by Bob Dylan, “My Generation” by The Who and “I Can't Get No Satisfaction” by The Rolling Stones. The following year Ike and Tina Turner released “River Deep - Mountain High”, The Supremes produced “You Can't Hurry Love” and The Beach Boys offered “Good Vibrations”. Bob Stanley, a musician and music historian, is a cheerleader for 1981, the year pop found its “way out of post-punk's monochrome predicament”, through the vivid colours of Adam and the Ants and the Human League. Jon Savage, a cultural historian, champions 1966, which along with those deathless singles was the year pop exploded into a psychedelic paisley swirl, the year of The Beatles's “Revolver” and The Beach Boys' “Pet Sounds”. There are those who insist it must be 1977, the year of the punk revolution, or acid house's second summer of love in 1988. Some aver that a span of years is more appropriate—perhaps hip-hop's golden age, from 1987 to 1993.

Painful though it may be for older music fans to admit, these past couple of years will have their supporters, especially among those who view pop as an agent of social change. These have been the years in which the music industry has started truly rebelling against the dominance of white men, in which abusers have been called out and in which more women, trans and non-binary artists have been thrust into the spotlight. Billie Eilish, Megan Thee Stallion, Taylor Swift, Dua Lipa and more have made records that will be discussed in music criticism for years to come.

Really, though, the best year for music is whenever you were young and the possibilities of the world were opening before you. It may not even matter what records came out that year. Mr Hepworth was 21 in 1971: no wonder it is his

annus mirabilis. In his book he accepts it is a natural inclination to associate a sense of musical wonder with youth, but he has an answer. “There's an important difference in the case of me and 1971. The difference is this: I'm right.” He's not. The correct answer is 1956, the year of Elvis Presley's debut as well as “Songs for Swingin' Lovers!”, “Lady Sings the Blues” and “Johnny Burnette and the Rock'n'Roll Trio”. But the discussion is enjoyable.

“1971: The Year That Music Changed Everything” is streaming on Apple TV+ now
